thread.title: Kitchen maker Magnet sees turnover fall but praises strong results before Brexit

author: Jonathon Manning
title: Kitchen maker Magnet sees turnover fall but praises strong results before Brexit
text:
Kitchen maker Magnet sees turnover fall but praises strong results before Brexit The Darlington company's operating profit fell by £4.4m during 2017 Share Kitchen specialist Magnet saw its turnover fall by nearly £20m last year (Image: Publicity Picture) Share Get business updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Kitchen specialist Magnet saw its turnover fall by nearly £20m last year, but has praised the results as “robust” due to Brexit affecting the UK market.
Revenue at Nobia Holdings UK Limited - which trades as Magnet - fell from £431.5m to £412.4m for the year ending December 2017.
The Darlington firm said that the drop in sales was largely due to uncertainty in the UK market.
Finance director Daniel Carr, writing in the company’s accounts, said: “In context to the UK market, the performance of the business continues to be robust.
“The UK kitchen market in 2017 is deemed to have weakened due to Brexit and elevated macroeconomic uncertainty. However, there is still a great need for new housing in the UK and sales to local builders are generally more resistant to economic declines than sales to consumers.
“The Magnet brand was repositioned during the year. This work resulted in a simplified purchasing process and a clearer offering. A new website and the ‘Magnet - Part of the family’ campaign were launched at the end of the year. Read More More than 70 jobs to go at Nestle Newcastle after production moved to Poland
“The profit for the year of £34.7m and the balance sheet as at December 31 2017 demonstrate that the financial position of the company remains strong with net assets of £159.7m.”
Operating profit at the firm also fell from £28.7m in 2016 to £24.3m. Profit after tax however, grew from £21.7m to £34.7m.
During the year the number of employees at the group fell from 2,417 to 2,338. As a result, the company’s staffing costs fell from £79.3m to £79m. Read More Mike Ashley wins legal battle with House of Fraser, sparking rumours of takeover bid
Magnet paid out a total of £1.548m to its directors, while total director remuneration in 2016 was £1.577m.
Mr Carr added: “The markets in which the company operates remain highly competitive and following the Brexit vote the outlook for the UK economy remains uncertain, however the directors are confident that the company is in a strong position in the market and well placed to prosper in future years.” Like us on Facebook
